title: Central and Peripheral Vestibular Impairment
chief_complaint: I have dizziness that happens when I change my head position, like looking up or bending over. I've also been unsteady on my feet for a long time, but my walking has gotten much worse over the last 6 years.

problem_summary.onset: Gait disturbance present for 25 years, worsened significantly 6 years ago. Severe 2-day vertigo episode occurred 6 years ago.
problem_summary.course: Progressive unsteadiness; episodic positional vertigo is intermittent.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss; Left vestibular weakness.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Nausea, light-headedness, true vertigo with position changes, scanning speech, anxiety, depression.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking second opinion regarding diagnosis and management.

history.present_illness: Patient reports intermittent episodic positional vertigo and persistent gait unsteadiness. Describes two dizziness types: 1) Nausea/vertigo with position change, 2) Worsening disequilibrium walking/standing.
history.otologic_history: History of 'Meniere's Disease' diagnosed 28 years ago (likely misdiagnosis). Severe vertigo event 6 years ago lasting 2 days. Reports bilateral hearing loss progressing slowly over 10 years.
history.medical_psych_history: Depression, Restless Leg Syndrome. Moderate alcohol intake (12 drinks/weekend) for 25 years.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) at 250-2000 Hz rising to normal at 3000-6000 Hz bilaterally. Left ear shows mild SNHL at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ability to receive and recognize speech.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral reflexes obtained at normal sensation levels bilaterally.

history.present_illness: Follow-up vestibular testing and specialty consults ordered after initial audio.
history.otologic_history: Otologist noted symptoms not consistent with Meniere's. Migrainous dizziness considered but criteria not met.
history.medical_psych_history: Positive for anxiety and depression on HADS.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG)
tests.key_findings: Persistent Downbeat Nystagmus (DBN) in center gaze, increasing with lateral/downward gaze. Horizontal rebound nystagmus. Abnormal smooth pursuit (saccadic intrusion, reduced gain). Reduced optokinetic gain.

tests.name: Rotary Chair
tests.key_findings: Abnormal phase leads at low frequencies. Abnormal VOR suppression. Normal gain and symmetry.

tests.name: cVEMP
tests.key_findings: Normal N1-P1 latency and amplitude values bilaterally.

tests.name: Neuro-ophthalmology Exam
tests.key_findings: Confirmed DBN with vision and vision denied. Positive Daroff sign. Subtle scanning speech (ataxic dysarthria).

tests.name: MRI Brain
tests.key_findings: Mild diffuse cerebellar and cerebral atrophy.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild, low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally with excellent speech recognition. Vestibular evaluation reveals a 'double hit' pathology: a peripheral left vestibular hypofunction (likely from a prior neuritis) and central vestibular impairment characterized by downbeat nystagmus, abnormal pursuit, and failure of VOR suppression. The central findings correlate with MRI-confirmed cerebellar atrophy, likely associated with long-term alcohol use, which is inhibiting compensation for the peripheral loss.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a mild hearing loss in the low pitches, but your ability to understand speech remains excellent.
Your dizziness has two causes: a weakness in your left inner ear (likely from the severe episode 6 years ago) and a processing issue in the balance center of your brain (cerebellum).
The 'processing' part of your brain is having trouble compensating for the inner ear weakness, which is why you still feel unsteady.
The MRI shows some shrinkage in the cerebellum, which is often related to long-term alcohol use. Reducing or stopping alcohol is critical to prevent further damage.
Because of your unsteadiness, fall prevention and safety in the home are very important priorities.
notes_for_actor: Portray a subtle speech abnormality: 'scanning speech' where you pause slightly between syllables or words.
You should appear unsteady when standing or walking, but you can sit comfortably.
Be honest about the alcohol use (12 drinks a weekend) but perhaps view it as 'normal' or 'moderate' until counseled otherwise.
You are frustrated that your balance has been getting worse despite seeing other doctors previously.
